Module filters.py¶

modules.filters.chromosome_filter(path_input, name)¶

With this filter we obtain the labels/titles for each cromosome of our file, e.g., in Leishmania case we’ll obtain the labels “LinJ.01”, “LinJ.02”, etc. This filter reads all the sequences in a FASTA file. Then with a prefix name, it adds a numbering in the format .XX, being X the numbers in order for each sequences it finds.

For example, for:

  • name = "LinJ"

  • A fasta file of 36 sequences:

The output would be:

['LinJ.01', 'LinJ.02', 'LinJ.03', 'LinJ.04', 'LinJ.05', 'LinJ.06', 'LinJ.07', 'LinJ.08', 'LinJ.09', 'LinJ.10', 'LinJ.11', 'LinJ.12', 'LinJ.13', 'LinJ.14', 'LinJ.15', 'LinJ.16', 'LinJ.17', 'LinJ.18', 'LinJ.19', 'LinJ.20', 'LinJ.21', 'LinJ.22', 'LinJ.23', 'LinJ.24', 'LinJ.25', 'LinJ.26', 'LinJ.27', 'LinJ.28', 'LinJ.29', 'LinJ.30', 'LinJ.31', 'LinJ.32', 'LinJ.33', 'LinJ.34', 'LinJ.35', 'LinJ.36']

The objective of this function is to be able to correctly name the files since programming languages do not usually admit a non-string format, numbers that start at 0, in this way we can automate their correct labeling, especially for numbers from 01 to 09 .

Attention

This IDs need to be matched exactly with the row[1] from the CSV to filter.

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the .fasta file to read.

  • name (string) – Name to give the results. In Leishmania’s case, it’s “LinJ”.

Returns

A python list with the chosen labels

Return type

Python list

modules.filters.dash_filter(path_input, writing_path_input)¶

With this function will filter all the “-” dashes in the sequences.

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to a CSV file we want to filter the data from. The data came from the output of filter_by_column().

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path to a CSV file where the filtered data will be written.

Returns

A CSV file with all the “-” dashes filtered.

Return type

CSV file

modules.filters.filter_by_column(path_input, column, size_filter, writing_path_input)¶

This function will filter a CSV data depending on length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent).

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file we want to filter data. It’s the output file created by blastn_blaster().

  • column (string) – Can be length (if we want to firlter by sequence length) or percent (if we want to filter by identity percent)

  • size_filter (integer) – Number to filter dependint of the column argument.

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file this function will create and save

Returns

A CSV file with the dalta filtered depending on the column and size_filter argumetns.

Return type

CSV file

modules.filters.global_filters_main(path_input, writing_path_input, genome_fasta, naming_short, max_diff)¶

This function mixes every other filter made. Each one writes a CSV which is overwritten every time till the final step.

Parameters

  • path_input (string) – Path to the CSV file we want to filter data. It’s the output file created by blastn_blaster().

  • writing_path_input (string) – Path where the CSV file will be saved.

  • genome_fasta (string) – Path to our whole genome sequence in FASTA format.

  • naming_short (string) – Label needed to read the ID of each cromosome in the .csv file. In the case of L. infantum for example, would be LinJ since the .csv file IDs are LinJ.XX.

  • max_diff (intenger) – Maximun proxomity value for the different sequences when they have to be grouped. Important.

Returns

All data filtered without duplications and overlaps.

Return type

CSV file
